awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding to support the participation of graduate students and other early-career researchers in the Second Drexel Waves Workshop, held March 30-31, 2023 at Drexel University in Philadelphia, PA. Wave propagation problems are ubiquitous in natural and engineered systems, arising in contexts such as fluid motion, optics, the motion of pedestrians and vehicles, systems from quantum physics, and more. 

Fifteen researchers have been invited to deliver lectures on wave propagation problems of high current interest. The invited speakers have expertise including mathematical analysis, modeling, asymptotic theory, and high-performance scientific computing. Specific topics discussed include fluid mixing problems, stability and metastability of coherent structures, and stochastic effects on wave propagation. The conference webpage is located at https://www.math.drexel.edu/~ambrose/drexelwaves/secondDWW.html.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Wave phenomena is ubiquitous in applied problems in engineering and science.  In many problems, the waves behave nonlinearly (i.e. for instance, if the energy input is doubled, the response is something other than a doubling in intensity).  This conference brought together experts in the mathematical theory and application of nonlinear waves, including experts at varying levels of seniority and with expertise in a variety of subfields of nonlinear waves research.  Fifteeen forty-minute lectures were delivered by faculty from Boston University, Brown University, Carnegie Mellon University, Drexel University, Hunter College, Kennesaw State University, New Jersey Institute of Technology, Pennsylvania State University, Seattle University, University of California at Berkeley, University of Houston, University of Pittsburgh, and University of Western Ontario.  The lectures included work in application areas such as fluid motion, chemical systems, materials science, and combustion, among others.  The work discussed included a mix of mathematical analysis, scientific computation, mathematical modeling, and dynamics, and discussions during and after the lectures benefitted from the presence of researchers with diverse viewpoints on related problems.

In addition to the speakers, fifteen junior researchers (graduate students and postdoctoral associates) were funded to fully participate in the meeting.  Of these, eight chose to present their own research during the conference's poster session.  There were also junior researchers (such as graduate students) from the local area in attendance at the meeting.

The meeting had many lively discussions and interactions on the state of the art of nonlinear waves research, including both current research as well as future directions for the field.


Last Modified: 09/08/2024
Modified by: David M Ambrose
